bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Act:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: application for dispute resolution means an application to the director under section 58 (1) [determining disputes];
approved form means the form approved by the director under section 10 (1) [director may approve forms] for the purposes of the section in which it appears;
common area means any part of residential property the use of which is shared by tenants, or by a landlord and one or more tenants;

director means the director appointed under section 8 [appointment of director] and, in relation to a power, duty or function of the director given to an employee referred to in section 9 (2) or delegated to a person retained under that section, includes that employee or person;
dispute resolution proceedings means proceedings started by making an application for dispute resolution under section 58 (1);
fixed term tenancy means a tenancy under a tenancy agreement that specifies the date on which the tenancy ends;
landlord, in relation to a rental unit, includes any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the owner of the rental unit, the owner's agent or another person who, on behalf of the landlord,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: permits occupation of the rental unit under a tenancy agreement, or
exercises powers and performs duties under this Act, the tenancy agreement or a service agreement;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the heirs, assigns, personal representatives and successors in title to a person referred to in paragraph (a);
a person, other than a tenant occupying the rental unit, who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is entitled to possession of the rental unit, and
exercises any of the rights of a landlord under a tenancy agreement or this Act in relation to the rental unit;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a former landlord, when the context requires this;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: manufactured home has the same meaning as in the Manufactured Home Park Tenancy Act;
periodic tenancy means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tenancy on a weekly, monthly or other periodic basis under a tenancy agreement that continues until it is ended in accordance with this Act, and

in relation to a fixed term tenancy agreement that does not provide that the tenant will vacate the rental unit at the end of the fixed term, a tenancy that arises under section 44 (3) [how a tenancy ends];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: pet damage deposit means money paid, or value or a right given, by or on behalf of a tenant to a landlord that is to be held as security for damage to residential property caused by a pet, but does not include

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a security deposit, or
a fee prescribed under section 97 (2) (k) [regulations in relation to fees];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: registered mail includes any method of mail delivery provided by Canada Post for which confirmation of delivery to a named person is available;

rent means money paid or agreed to be paid, or value or a right given or agreed to be given, by or on behalf of a tenant to a landlord in return for the right to possess a rental unit, for the use of common areas and for services or facilities, but does not include any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a security deposit;
a pet damage deposit;
a fee prescribed under section 97 (2) (k) [regulations in relation to fees];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: rental unit means living accommodation rented or intended to be rented to a tenant;
residential property means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a building, a part of a building or a related group of buildings, in which one or more rental units or common areas are located,
the parcel or parcels on which the building, related group of buildings or common areas are located,
the rental unit and common areas, and
any other structure located on the parcel or parcels;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: security deposit means money paid, or value or a right given, by or on behalf of a tenant to a landlord that is to be held as security for any liability or obligation of the tenant respecting the residential property, but does not include any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: post-dated cheques for rent;
a pet damage deposit;
a fee prescribed under section 97 (2) (k) [regulations in relation to fees];

bcl:definition.bcl:text: service or facility includes any of the following that are provided or agreed to be provided by the landlord to the tenant of a rental unit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: appliances and furnishings;
utilities and related services;
cleaning and maintenance services;
parking spaces and related facilities;
cablevision facilities;
laundry facilities;
storage facilities;
elevator;
common recreational facilities;
intercom systems;
garbage facilities and related services;
heating facilities or services;
housekeeping services;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: standard terms means the standard terms of a tenancy agreement prescribed in the regulations;
sublease agreement means a tenancy agreement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: under which

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the tenant of a rental unit transfers the tenant's rights under the tenancy agreement to a subtenant for a period shorter than the term of the tenant's tenancy agreement, and
the subtenant agrees to vacate the rental unit at the end of the term of the sublease agreement, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that specifies the date on which the tenancy under the sublease agreement ends;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: tenancy means a tenant's right to possession of a rental unit under a tenancy agreement;

tenancy agreement means an agreement, whether written or oral, express or implied, between a landlord and a tenant respecting possession of a rental unit, use of common areas and services and facilities, and includes a licence to occupy a rental unit;
tenant includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the estate of a deceased tenant, and
when the context requires, a former or prospective tenant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite any other enactment but subject to section 4 [what this Act does not apply to], this Act applies to tenancy agreements, rental units and other residential property.
Except as otherwise provided in this Act, this Act applies to a tenancy agreement entered into before or after the date this Act comes into force.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Act applies to tenancy agreement with a minor
bcl:section.bcl:text: A person who has not reached 19 years of age may enter into a tenancy agreement or a service agreement, and the agreement and this Act and the regulations are enforceable by and against the person despite section 19 of the Infants Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: What this Act does not apply to
bcl:section.bcl:text: This Act does not apply to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: living accommodation rented by a not for profit housing cooperative to a member of the cooperative,
living accommodation owned or operated by an educational institution and provided by that institution to its students or employees,
living accommodation in which the tenant shares bathroom or kitchen facilities with the owner of that accommodation,
living accommodation included with premises that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are primarily occupied for business purposes, and
are rented under a single agreement,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: living accommodation occupied as vacation or travel accommodation,
living accommodation provided for emergency shelter or transitional housing,
living accommodation

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in a community care facility under the Community Care and Assisted Living Act,
in a continuing care facility under the Continuing Care Act,
in a public or private hospital under the Hospital Act,
if designated under the Mental Health Act, in a Provincial mental health facility, an observation unit or a psychiatric unit,
in a housing based health facility that provides hospitality support services and personal health care, or
that is made available in the course of providing rehabilitative or therapeutic treatment or services,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: living accommodation in a correctional institution,
living accommodation rented under a tenancy agreement that has a term longer than 20 years,
tenancy agreements to which the Manufactured Home Park Tenancy Act applies, or
prescribed tenancy agreements, rental units or residential property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Landlords and tenants may not avoid or contract out of this Act or the regulations.
Any attempt to avoid or contract out of this Act or the regulations is of no effect.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of the Administrative Tribunals Act
bcl:section.bcl:text: Sections 1, 44, 46.3, 48, 56 to 58 and 61 of the Administrative Tribunals Act apply to the director as if the director were a tribunal and to dispute resolution proceedings under Division 1 of Part 5, reviews under Division 2 of Part 5 and the imposition and review of administrative penalties under Part 5.1.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Enforcing rights and obligations of landlords and tenants

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The rights, obligations and prohibitions established under this Act are enforceable between a landlord and tenant under a tenancy agreement.
A landlord or tenant may make an application for dispute resolution if the landlord and tenant cannot resolve a dispute referred to in section 58 (1) [determining disputes].
A term of a tenancy agreement is not enforceable if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the term is inconsistent with this Act or the regulations,
the term is unconscionable, or
the term is not expressed in a manner that clearly communicates the rights and obligations under it.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Liability for not complying with this Act or a tenancy agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a landlord or tenant does not comply with this Act, the regulations or their tenancy agreement, the non-complying landlord or tenant must compensate the other for damage or loss that results.

A landlord or tenant who claims compensation for damage or loss that results from the other's non-compliance with this Act, the regulations or their tenancy agreement must do whatever is reasonable to minimize the damage or loss.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A director must be appointed in accordance with the Public Service Act for the purposes of this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director is responsible for the administration and management of all matters and persons appointed or retained under this Act.

Employees may be appointed under the Public Service Act, and the director may retain other persons, whom the director considers necessary to exercise the director's powers and perform the director's duties and functions under this Act.
The director may establish and publish rules of procedure for the conduct of proceedings under Parts 5 [Resolving Disputes] and 5.1 [Administrative Penalties].

The director may not assign or delegate to the same person both the function of conducting investigations under section 87.1 [investigations] into a matter and the power to impose penalties under section 87.3 [administrative penalties] in relation to that matter.
The director may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: provide information to landlords and tenants about their rights and obligations under this Act;
help landlords and tenants resolve any dispute in relation to which an application for dispute resolution has been or may be made;
publish, or otherwise make available to the public, decisions or orders under Part 5 or summaries of them;
publish, or otherwise make available to the public, the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: notices, decisions, orders or agreements made under Part 5.1 or summaries of them;
penalty payment status.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's power to delegate to contractors

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may delegate to a person retained under section 9 (2) any of the director's powers, duties or functions under this Act, except the power under section 9 (3) and the power to delegate under this section.
A delegation under subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be cancelled,
does not prevent the director from carrying out the delegated power, duty or function, and
may be subject to the terms or conditions the director considers appropriate.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the director ceases to hold office, a delegation under this section continues in effect

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the duration of the contract, or
until cancelled by a succeeding director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who claims to be carrying out a power, duty or function delegated by the director under this section, on request, must produce evidence of the delegation.
The director may approve forms for the purposes of this Act.
Deviations from an approved form that do not affect its substance and are not intended to mislead do not invalidate the form used.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director and staff must not be compelled in civil proceedings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director and persons employed, engaged or retained under section 9 (2) [director's powers and duties] must not be compelled in civil proceedings arising out of a dispute under this Act

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to give evidence in respect of matters that come to their knowledge in the course of their employment, or
to produce records that are in the possession of the director because of the director's powers or duties under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (1), the court may require the director to produce the record of a dispute resolution proceeding that is the subject of an application for judicial review under the Judicial Review Procedure Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tenancy agreements include the standard terms
bcl:section.bcl:text: The standard terms are terms of every tenancy agreement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether the tenancy agreement was entered into on or before, or after, January 1, 2004, and
whether or not the tenancy agreement is in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must prepare in writing every tenancy agreement entered into on or after January 1, 2004.
A tenancy agreement must comply with any requirements prescribed in the regulations and must set out all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the standard terms;
the correct legal names of the landlord and tenant;
the address of the rental unit;
the date the tenancy agreement is entered into;
the address for service and telephone number of the landlord or the landlord's agent;
the agreed terms in respect of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date on which the tenancy starts;
if the tenancy is a periodic tenancy, whether it is on a weekly, monthly or other periodic basis;
if the tenancy is a fixed term tenancy, the date on which the term ends;
if the tenancy is a fixed term tenancy in circumstances prescribed under section 97 (2) (a.1), that the tenant must vacate the rental unit at the end of the term;
the amount of rent payable for a specified period, and, if the rent varies with the number of occupants, the amount by which it varies;
the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, on which the rent is due;
which services and facilities are included in the rent;
the amount of any security deposit or pet damage deposit and the date the security deposit or pet damage deposit was or must be paid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Within 21 days after a landlord and tenant enter into a tenancy agreement, the landlord must give the tenant a copy of the agreement.
A tenancy agreement may not be amended to change or remove a standard term.
A tenancy agreement may be amended to add, remove or change a term, other than a standard term, only if both the landlord and tenant agree to the amendment.
The requirement for agreement under subsection (2) does not apply to any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a rent increase in accordance with Part 3 of this Act;
a withdrawal of, or a restriction on, a service or facility in accordance with section 27 [terminating or restricting services or facilities];
a term in respect of which a landlord or tenant has obtained an order of the director that the agreement of the other is not required.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A landlord must not charge a person anything for

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: accepting an application for a tenancy,
processing the application,
investigating the applicant's suitability as a tenant, or
accepting the person as a tenant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Start of rights and obligations under tenancy agreement
bcl:section.bcl:text: The rights and obligations of a landlord and tenant under a tenancy agreement take effect from the date the tenancy agreement is entered into, whether or not the tenant ever occupies the rental unit.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Other Specific Terms in a Tenancy Agreement

bcl:section.bcl:text: A landlord may require, in accordance with this Act and the regulations, a tenant to pay a security deposit as a condition of entering into a tenancy agreement or as a term of a tenancy agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Terms respecting pets and pet damage deposits

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenancy agreement may include terms or conditions doing either or both of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prohibiting pets, or restricting the size, kind or number of pets a tenant may keep on the residential property;
governing a tenant's obligations in respect of keeping a pet on the residential property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, after January 1, 2004, a landlord permits a tenant to keep a pet on the residential property, the landlord may require the tenant to pay a pet damage deposit in accordance with sections 19 [limits on amount of deposits] and 20 [landlord prohibitions respecting deposits].
This section is subject to the Guide Dog and Service Dog Act.
A landlord must not require or accept either a security deposit or a pet damage deposit that is greater than the equivalent of 1/2 of one month's rent payable under the tenancy agreement.

If a landlord accepts a security deposit or a pet damage deposit that is greater than the amount permitted under subsection (1), the tenant may deduct the overpayment from rent or otherwise recover the overpayment.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A landlord must not do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require a security deposit at any time other than when the landlord and tenant enter into the tenancy agreement;
require or accept more than one security deposit in respect of a tenancy agreement;
require a pet damage deposit at any time other than

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: when the landlord and tenant enter into the tenancy agreement, or
if the tenant acquires a pet during the term of a tenancy agreement, when the landlord agrees that the tenant may keep the pet on the residential property;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require or accept more than one pet damage deposit in respect of a tenancy agreement, irrespective of the number of pets the landlord agrees the tenant may keep on the residential property;
require, or include as a term of a tenancy agreement, that the landlord automatically keeps all or part of the security deposit or the pet damage deposit at the end of the tenancy agreement.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Unless the landlord gives written consent, a tenant must not apply a security deposit or a pet damage deposit as rent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: cannabis has the same meaning as in the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act;
cannabis control date means the date that section 14 of the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act comes into force;
cannabis plant has the same meaning as in the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act;
grow means to cultivate, propagate or harvest;
medical cannabis has the same meaning as in the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a tenancy agreement entered into before the cannabis control date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: includes a term that prohibits or limits smoking tobacco, and
does not include a term that expressly permits smoking cannabis,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the tenancy agreement is deemed to include a term that prohibits or limits smoking cannabis in the same manner as smoking tobacco is prohibited or limited.
For greater certainty, vapourizing a substance containing cannabis is not smoking cannabis for the purpose of subsection (2).

A tenancy agreement entered into before the cannabis control date is deemed to include a term that prohibits growing cannabis plants in or on the residential property unless, on the day before the cannabis control date,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant is growing in or on the residential property one or more cannabis plants that are medical cannabis,
growing the plants is not contrary to a term of the tenancy agreement, and

the tenant is authorized under applicable federal law to grow the plants in or on the residential property and the tenant is in compliance with the requirements under that law with respect to the medical cannabis.

bcl:section.bcl:text: A tenancy agreement must not include a term that all or part of the rent payable for the remainder of the period of the tenancy agreement becomes due and payable if a term of the tenancy agreement is breached.

bcl:division.bcl:text: At the Start of a Tenancy

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Condition inspection: start of tenancy or new pet

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The landlord and tenant together must inspect the condition of the rental unit on the day the tenant is entitled to possession of the rental unit or on another mutually agreed day.
The landlord and tenant together must inspect the condition of the rental unit on or before the day the tenant starts keeping a pet or on another mutually agreed day, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord permits the tenant to keep a pet on the residential property after the start of a tenancy, and
a previous inspection was not completed under subsection (1).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The landlord must offer the tenant at least 2 opportunities, as prescribed, for the inspection.
The landlord must complete a condition inspection report in accordance with the regulations.
Both the landlord and tenant must sign the condition inspection report and the landlord must give the tenant a copy of that report in accordance with the regulations.
The landlord must make the inspection and complete and sign the report without the tenant if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord has complied with subsection (3), and
the tenant does not participate on either occasion.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consequences for tenant and landlord if report requirements not met

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The right of a tenant to the return of a security deposit or a pet damage deposit, or both, is extinguished if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord has complied with section 23 (3) [2 opportunities for inspection], and
the tenant has not participated on either occasion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The right of a landlord to claim against a security deposit or a pet damage deposit, or both, for damage to residential property is extinguished if the landlord

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not comply with section 23 (3) [2 opportunities for inspection],
having complied with section 23 (3), does not participate on either occasion, or
does not complete the condition inspection report and give the tenant a copy of it in accordance with the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: At the request of a tenant at the start of a new tenancy, the landlord must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: rekey or otherwise alter the locks so that keys or other means of access given to the previous tenant do not give access to the rental unit, and
pay all costs associated with the changes under paragraph (a).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the landlord already complied with subsection (1) (a) and (b) at the end of the previous tenancy, the landlord need not do so again.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rules about payment and non-payment of rent

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant must pay rent when it is due under the tenancy agreement, whether or not the landlord complies with this Act, the regulations or the tenancy agreement, unless the tenant has a right under this Act to deduct all or a portion of the rent.
A landlord must provide a tenant with a receipt for rent paid in cash.
Whether or not a tenant pays rent in accordance with the tenancy agreement, a landlord must not

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: seize any personal property of the tenant, or
prevent or interfere with the tenant's access to the tenant's personal property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) (a) does not apply if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord has a court order authorizing the action, or
the tenant has abandoned the rental unit and the landlord complies with the regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Terminating or restricting services or facilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must not terminate or restrict a service or facility if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the service or facility is essential to the tenant's use of the rental unit as living accommodation, or
providing the service or facility is a material term of the tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may terminate or restrict a service or facility, other than one referred to in subsection (1), if the landlord

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: gives 30 days' written notice, in the approved form, of the termination or restriction, and
reduces the rent in an amount that is equivalent to the reduction in the value of the tenancy agreement resulting from the termination or restriction of the service or facility.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Protection of tenant's right to quiet enjoyment
bcl:section.bcl:text: A tenant is entitled to quiet enjoyment including, but not limited to, rights to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: reasonable privacy;
freedom from unreasonable disturbance;
exclusive possession of the rental unit subject only to the landlord's right to enter the rental unit in accordance with section 29 [landlord's right to enter rental unit restricted];
use of common areas for reasonable and lawful purposes, free from significant interference.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Landlord's right to enter rental unit restricted

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must not enter a rental unit that is subject to a tenancy agreement for any purpose unless one of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant gives permission at the time of the entry or not more than 30 days before the entry;
at least 24 hours and not more than 30 days before the entry, the landlord gives the tenant written notice that includes the following information:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the purpose for entering, which must be reasonable;
the date and the time of the entry, which must be between 8 a.m. and 9 p.m. unless the tenant otherwise agrees;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord provides housekeeping or related services under the terms of a written tenancy agreement and the entry is for that purpose and in accordance with those terms;
the landlord has an order of the director authorizing the entry;
the tenant has abandoned the rental unit;
an emergency exists and the entry is necessary to protect life or property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may inspect a rental unit monthly in accordance with subsection (1) (b).
A landlord must not unreasonably restrict access to residential property by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant of a rental unit that is part of the residential property, or
a person permitted on the residential property by that tenant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must not unreasonably restrict access to residential property by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a candidate seeking election to the Parliament of Canada, the Legislative Assembly or an office in an election under the Local Government Act, the School Act or the Vancouver Charter, or
the authorized representative of such a person

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: who is canvassing electors or distributing election material.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prohibitions on changes to locks and other access

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must not change locks or other means that give access to residential property unless the landlord provides each tenant with new keys or other means that give access to the residential property.
A landlord must not change locks or other means of access to a rental unit unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant agrees to the change, and
the landlord provides the tenant with new keys or other means of access to the rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant must not change locks or other means that give access to common areas of residential property unless the landlord consents to the change.
A tenant must not change a lock or other means that gives access to the tenant's rental unit unless the landlord agrees in writing to, or the director has ordered, the change.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Landlord and tenant obligations to repair and maintain

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must provide and maintain residential property in a state of decoration and repair that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: complies with the health, safety and housing standards required by law, and
having regard to the age, character and location of the rental unit, makes it suitable for occupation by a tenant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant must maintain reasonable health, cleanliness and sanitary standards throughout the rental unit and the other residential property to which the tenant has access.
A tenant of a rental unit must repair damage to the rental unit or common areas that is caused by the actions or neglect of the tenant or a person permitted on the residential property by the tenant.
A tenant is not required to make repairs for reasonable wear and tear.
A landlord's obligations under subsection (1) (a) apply whether or not a tenant knew of a breach by the landlord of that subsection at the time of entering into the tenancy agreement.
In this section, emergency repairs means repairs that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: urgent,
necessary for the health or safety of anyone or for the preservation or use of residential property, and
made for the purpose of repairing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: major leaks in pipes or the roof,
damaged or blocked water or sewer pipes or plumbing fixtures,
the primary heating system,
damaged or defective locks that give access to a rental unit,
the electrical systems, or
in prescribed circumstances, a rental unit or residential property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The landlord must post and maintain in a conspicuous place on residential property, or give to a tenant in writing, the name and telephone number of a person the tenant is to contact for emergency repairs.
A tenant may have emergency repairs made only when all of the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: emergency repairs are needed;
the tenant has made at least 2 attempts to telephone, at the number provided, the person identified by the landlord as the person to contact for emergency repairs;
following those attempts, the tenant has given the landlord reasonable time to make the repairs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may take over completion of an emergency repair at any time.
A landlord must reimburse a tenant for amounts paid for emergency repairs if the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: claims reimbursement for those amounts from the landlord, and
gives the landlord a written account of the emergency repairs accompanied by a receipt for each amount claimed.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (5) does not apply to amounts claimed by a tenant for repairs about which the director, on application, finds that one or more of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant made the repairs before one or more of the conditions in subsection (3) were met;
the tenant has not provided the account and receipts for the repairs as required under subsection (5) (b);
the amounts represent more than a reasonable cost for the repairs;
the emergency repairs are for damage caused primarily by the actions or neglect of the tenant or a person permitted on the residential property by the tenant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a landlord does not reimburse a tenant as required under subsection (5), the tenant may deduct the amount from rent or otherwise recover the amount.
Unless the landlord consents in writing, a tenant must not assign a tenancy agreement or sublet a rental unit.
If a fixed term tenancy agreement has 6 months or more remaining in the term, the landlord must not unreasonably withhold the consent required under subsection (1).
A landlord must not charge a tenant anything for considering, investigating or consenting to an assignment or sublease under this section.

bcl:division.bcl:text: At the End of a Tenancy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The landlord and tenant together must inspect the condition of the rental unit before a new tenant begins to occupy the rental unit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on or after the day the tenant ceases to occupy the rental unit, or
on another mutually agreed day.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The landlord must offer the tenant at least 2 opportunities, as prescribed, for the inspection.
The landlord must complete a condition inspection report in accordance with the regulations.
Both the landlord and tenant must sign the condition inspection report and the landlord must give the tenant a copy of that report in accordance with the regulations.
The landlord may make the inspection and complete and sign the report without the tenant if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord has complied with subsection (2) and the tenant does not participate on either occasion, or
the tenant has abandoned the rental unit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Consequences for tenant and landlord if report requirements not met

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The right of a tenant to the return of a security deposit or a pet damage deposit, or both, is extinguished if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord complied with section 35 (2) [2 opportunities for inspection], and
the tenant has not participated on either occasion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless the tenant has abandoned the rental unit, the right of the landlord to claim against a security deposit or a pet damage deposit, or both, for damage to residential property is extinguished if the landlord

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not comply with section 35 (2) [2 opportunities for inspection],
having complied with section 35 (2), does not participate on either occasion, or
having made an inspection with the tenant, does not complete the condition inspection report and give the tenant a copy of it in accordance with the regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Leaving the rental unit at the end of a tenancy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless a landlord and tenant otherwise agree, the tenant must vacate the rental unit by 1 p.m. on the day the tenancy ends.
When a tenant vacates a rental unit, the tenant must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: leave the rental unit reasonably clean, and undamaged except for reasonable wear and tear, and
give the landlord all the keys or other means of access that are in the possession or control of the tenant and that allow access to and within the residential property.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Return of security deposit and pet damage deposit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in subsection (3) or (4) (a), within 15 days after the later of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the date the tenancy ends, and
the date the landlord receives the tenant's forwarding address in writing,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the landlord must do one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: repay, as provided in subsection (8), any security deposit or pet damage deposit to the tenant with interest calculated in accordance with the regulations;
make an application for dispute resolution claiming against the security deposit or pet damage deposit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) does not apply if the tenant's right to the return of a security deposit or a pet damage deposit has been extinguished under section 24 (1) [tenant fails to participate in start of tenancy inspection] or 36 (1) [tenant fails to participate in end of tenancy inspection].
A landlord may retain from a security deposit or a pet damage deposit an amount that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the director has previously ordered the tenant to pay to the landlord, and
at the end of the tenancy remains unpaid.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may retain an amount from a security deposit or a pet damage deposit if,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: at the end of a tenancy, the tenant agrees in writing the landlord may retain the amount to pay a liability or obligation of the tenant, or
after the end of the tenancy, the director orders that the landlord may retain the amount.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The right of a landlord to retain all or part of a security deposit or pet damage deposit under subsection (4) (a) does not apply if the liability of the tenant is in relation to damage and the landlord's right to claim for damage against a security deposit or a pet damage deposit has been extinguished under section 24 (2) [landlord failure to meet start of tenancy condition report requirements] or 36 (2) [landlord failure to meet end of tenancy condition report requirements].
If a landlord does not comply with subsection (1), the landlord

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may not make a claim against the security deposit or any pet damage deposit, and
must pay the tenant double the amount of the security deposit, pet damage deposit, or both, as applicable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a landlord is entitled to retain an amount under subsection (3) or (4), a pet damage deposit may be used only for damage caused by a pet to the residential property, unless the tenant agrees otherwise.
For the purposes of subsection (1) (c), the landlord must repay a deposit

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the same way as a record may be served under section 88 (c), (d) or (f) [service of records],
by giving the deposit personally to the tenant, or
by using any form of electronic

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: payment to the tenant, or
transfer of funds to the tenant.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order for return of security and pet damage deposit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant, by making an application under Part 5 [Resolving Disputes] for dispute resolution, may request an order for the return of an amount that is double the portion of the security deposit or pet damage deposit or both to which all of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord has not applied to the director within the time set out in section 38 (1) claiming against that portion;
there is no order referred to in section 38 (3) or (4) (b) applicable to that portion;
there is no agreement under section 38 (4) (a) applicable to that portion.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the circumstances described in subsection (1), the director, without any further dispute resolution process, may grant an order for the return of the amount referred to in subsection (1) and interest on that amount in accordance with section 38 (1) (c).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Landlord may retain deposits if forwarding address not provided
bcl:section.bcl:text: Despite any other provision of this Act, if a tenant does not give a landlord a forwarding address in writing within one year after the end of the tenancy,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord may keep the security deposit or the pet damage deposit, or both, and
the right of the tenant to the return of the security deposit or pet damage deposit is extinguished.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part, rent increase does not include an increase in rent that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for one or more additional occupants, and
is authorized under the tenancy agreement by a term referred to in section 13 (2) (f) (iv) [requirements for tenancy agreements: additional occupants].

bcl:section.bcl:text: A landlord must not increase rent except in accordance with this Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Timing and notice of rent increases

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must not impose a rent increase for at least 12 months after whichever of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the tenant's rent has not previously been increased, the date on which the tenant's rent was first payable for the rental unit;
if the tenant's rent has previously been increased, the effective date of the last rent increase made in accordance with this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord must give a tenant notice of a rent increase at least 3 months before the effective date of the increase.
A notice of a rent increase must be in the approved form.
If a landlord's notice of a rent increase does not comply with subsections (1) and (2), the notice takes effect on the earliest date that does comply.
A landlord may impose a rent increase only up to the amount

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: calculated in accordance with the regulations,
ordered by the director on an application under subsection (3), or
agreed to by the tenant in writing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant may not make an application for dispute resolution to dispute a rent increase that complies with this Part.

In the circumstances prescribed in the regulations, a landlord may request the director's approval of a rent increase in an amount that is greater than the amount calculated under the regulations referred to in subsection (1) (a) by making an application for dispute resolution.
If a landlord collects a rent increase that does not comply with this Part, the tenant may deduct the increase from rent or otherwise recover the increase.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of rent increase has no effect

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of this section, a date that applies under section 90 (a), (b), (c) or (d), or that is prescribed under section 97 (2) (p), as the date a notice is deemed to be received is the date that applies regardless of whether the notice is received earlier or later than that date.
A notice given under this Part for an increase based on a calculation made under section 43 (1) (a) has no effect if the notice

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is received before September 30, 2021, as determined under subsection (1) of this section, and
has an effective date that is after March 30, 2020 and before January 1, 2022.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenancy ends only if one or more of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant or landlord gives notice to end the tenancy in accordance with one of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 45 [tenant's notice];
section 45.1 [tenant's notice: family violence or long-term care];
section 46 [landlord's notice: non-payment of rent];
section 47 [landlord's notice: cause];
section 48 [landlord's notice: end of employment];
section 49 [landlord's notice: landlord's use of property];
section 49.1 [landlord's notice: tenant ceases to qualify];
section 50 [tenant may end tenancy early];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenancy agreement is a fixed term tenancy agreement that, in circumstances prescribed under section 97 (2) (a.1), requires the tenant to vacate the rental unit at the end of the term;
the landlord and tenant agree in writing to end the tenancy;
the tenant vacates or abandons the rental unit;
the tenancy agreement is frustrated;
the director orders that the tenancy is ended;
the tenancy agreement is a sublease agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, on the date specified as the end of a fixed term tenancy agreement that does not require the tenant to vacate the rental unit on that date, the landlord and tenant have not entered into a new tenancy agreement, the landlord and tenant are deemed to have renewed the tenancy agreement as a month to month tenancy on the same terms.
A tenant may end a periodic tenancy by giving the landlord notice to end the tenancy effective on a date that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not earlier than one month after the date the landlord receives the notice, and
is the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant may end a fixed term tenancy by giving the landlord notice to end the tenancy effective on a date that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not earlier than one month after the date the landlord receives the notice,
is not earlier than the date specified in the tenancy agreement as the end of the tenancy, and
is the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a landlord has failed to comply with a material term of the tenancy agreement and has not corrected the situation within a reasonable period after the tenant gives written notice of the failure, the tenant may end the tenancy effective on a date that is after the date the landlord receives the notice.
A notice to end a tenancy given under this section must comply with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy].

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tenant's notice: family violence or long-term care

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section and section 45.2:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: family member has the same meaning as in the Family Law Act;
family violence has the same meaning as in the Family Law Act;

household violence means violence, with or without an intent to harm a tenant or occupant, that has adversely affected a tenant's or occupant's quiet enjoyment, security, safety or physical well-being or is likely to adversely affect those if the tenant or occupant remains in a rental unit, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: physical abuse of the tenant or occupant, including forced confinement or deprivation of the necessities of life, but not including the use of reasonable force to protect oneself or others from harm,
sexual abuse of the tenant or occupant,
attempts to physically or sexually abuse the tenant or occupant,
psychological or emotional abuse of the tenant or occupant, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: intimidation, harassment, coercion or threats, including threats respecting other persons, pets or property,
unreasonable restrictions on, or prevention of, the financial or personal autonomy of the tenant or occupant,
stalking or following the tenant or occupant, and
intentional damage to property, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of an individual under the age of 19, direct or indirect exposure to violence against the tenant or occupant;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: long-term care means personal or health care provided in a long-term care facility to a person who is unlikely to return to living independently under a tenancy agreement;
long-term care facility means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a community care facility under the Community Care and Assisted Living Act;
a facility that, under the Continuing Care Act, provides a program of continuing care in the form of residential care;
a hospital within the meaning of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: paragraph (c) of the definition of "hospital" in section 1 of the Hospital Act, or
section 5 of that Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: occupant means an individual, other than a tenant, who occupies a rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant is eligible to end a fixed term tenancy under this section if a statement is made in accordance with section 45.2 [confirmation of eligibility] confirming one of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the tenant remains in the rental unit, the safety or security of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: either the tenant or a dependant of the tenant who lives in the rental unit is or is likely at risk from family violence carried out by a family member of the tenant, or
either the tenant or occupant is or is likely at risk from household violence;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant has been assessed as requiring long-term care;
the tenant has been admitted to a long-term care facility.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant under this section may end a fixed term tenancy by giving the landlord notice to end the tenancy effective on a date that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is not earlier than one month after the date the landlord receives the notice, and
is the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice to end a tenancy given under this section must comply with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy].
For certainty, a reference in this section or section 45.2 to "occupant" includes a dependant of a tenant or occupant, if the dependant occupies the rental unit.
A person may make a statement confirming a tenant's eligibility to end a fixed term tenancy under section 45.1 [tenant's notice: family violence or long-term care] only if the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is authorized to do so under the regulations, and
has assessed, in accordance with the regulations, the tenant and the tenant's circumstances and, if applicable in respect of household violence, the occupant and the occupant's circumstances.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who makes a statement under this section must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: make the statement in the approved form, and
keep records as required by the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In a proceeding under this Act, a person who makes a statement under this section is compellable to disclose or provide evidence respecting the following types of information only:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: evidence respecting the person's authority, for the purposes of subsection (1) (a), to make the statement;
evidence respecting the veracity of the signature appearing on the statement.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Termination by one of a group of tenants
bcl:section.bcl:text: If a fixed term tenancy is ended under section 45.1 [tenant's notice: family violence or long-term care] by one of 2 or more tenants who are subject to the same tenancy agreement, the remaining tenant or tenants must also vacate the rental unit, unless the remaining tenant or tenants enter into a new tenancy agreement with the landlord.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may end a tenancy if rent is unpaid on any day after the day it is due, by giving notice to end the tenancy effective on a date that is not earlier than 10 days after the date the tenant receives the notice.
A notice under this section must comply with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy].
A notice under this section has no effect if the amount of rent that is unpaid is an amount the tenant is permitted under this Act to deduct from rent.
Within 5 days after receiving a notice under this section, the tenant may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pay the overdue rent, in which case the notice has no effect, or
dispute the notice by making an application for dispute resolution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a tenant who has received a notice under this section does not pay the rent or make an application for dispute resolution in accordance with subsection (4), the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is conclusively presumed to have accepted that the tenancy ends on the effective date of the notice, and
must vacate the rental unit to which the notice relates by that date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a tenancy agreement requires the tenant to pay utility charges to the landlord, and
the utility charges are unpaid more than 30 days after the tenant is given a written demand for payment of them,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: the landlord may treat the unpaid utility charges as unpaid rent and may give notice under this section.
A landlord may end a tenancy by giving notice to end the tenancy if one or more of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant does not pay the security deposit or pet damage deposit within 30 days of the date it is required to be paid under the tenancy agreement;
the tenant is repeatedly late paying rent;
there are an unreasonable number of occupants in a rental unit;
the tenant or a person permitted on the residential property by the tenant has

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: significantly interfered with or unreasonably disturbed another occupant or the landlord of the residential property,
seriously jeopardized the health or safety or a lawful right or interest of the landlord or another occupant, or
put the landlord's property at significant risk;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant or a person permitted on the residential property by the tenant has engaged in illegal activity that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has caused or is likely to cause damage to the landlord's property,
has adversely affected or is likely to adversely affect the quiet enjoyment, security, safety or physical well-being of another occupant of the residential property, or
has jeopardized or is likely to jeopardize a lawful right or interest of another occupant or the landlord;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant or a person permitted on the residential property by the tenant has caused extraordinary damage to a rental unit or residential property;
the tenant does not repair damage to the rental unit or other residential property, as required under section 32 (3) [obligations to repair and maintain], within a reasonable time;
the tenant

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: has failed to comply with a material term, and
has not corrected the situation within a reasonable time after the landlord gives written notice to do so;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant purports to assign the tenancy agreement or sublet the rental unit without first obtaining the landlord's written consent as required by section 34 [assignment and subletting];
the tenant knowingly gives false information about the residential property to a prospective tenant or purchaser viewing the residential property;
the rental unit must be vacated to comply with an order of a federal, British Columbia, regional or municipal government authority;
the tenant has not complied with an order of the director within 30 days of the later of the following dates:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the date the tenant receives the order;
the date specified in the order for the tenant to comply with the order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under this section must end the tenancy effective on a date that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not earlier than one month after the date the notice is received, and
the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under this section must comply with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy].
A tenant may dispute a notice under this section by making an application for dispute resolution within 10 days after the date the tenant receives the notice.
If a tenant who has received a notice under this section does not make an application for dispute resolution in accordance with subsection (4), the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is conclusively presumed to have accepted that the tenancy ends on the effective date of the notice, and
must vacate the rental unit by that date.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Landlord's notice: end of employment with the landlord

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may end the tenancy of a person employed as a caretaker, manager or superintendent of the residential property of which the rental unit is a part by giving notice to end the tenancy if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the rental unit was rented or provided to the tenant for the term of the tenant's employment,
the tenant's employment as a caretaker, manager or superintendent is ended, and
the landlord intends in good faith to rent or provide the rental unit to a new caretaker, manager or superintendent.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An employer may end the tenancy of an employee in respect of a rental unit rented or provided by the employer to the employee to occupy during the term of employment by giving notice to end the tenancy if the employment is ended.
A notice under this section must end the tenancy effective on a date that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not earlier than one month after the date the tenant receives the notice,
not earlier than the last day the tenant is employed by the landlord, and
the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent, if any, is payable under the tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under this section must comply with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy].
A tenant may dispute a notice under this section by making an application for dispute resolution within 10 days after the date the tenant receives the notice.
If a tenant who has received a notice under this section does not make an application for dispute resolution in accordance with subsection (5), the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is conclusively presumed to have accepted that the tenancy ends on the effective date of the notice, and
must vacate the rental unit by that date.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Landlord's notice: landlord's use of property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: close family member means, in relation to an individual,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the individual's parent, spouse or child, or
the parent or child of that individual's spouse;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: family corporation means a corporation in which all the voting shares are owned by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one individual, or
one individual plus one or more of that individual's siblings or close family members;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: landlord means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purposes of subsection (3), an individual who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at the time of giving the notice, has a reversionary interest in the rental unit exceeding 3 years, and
holds not less than 1/2 of the full reversionary interest, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purposes of subsection (4), a family corporation that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at the time of giving the notice, has a reversionary interest in the rental unit exceeding 3 years, and
holds not less than 1/2 of the full reversionary interest;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: purchaser, for the purposes of subsection (5), means a purchaser that has agreed to purchase at least 1/2 of the full reversionary interest in the rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 51 [tenant's compensation: section 49 notice], a landlord may end a tenancy

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a purpose referred to in subsection (3), (4) or (5) by giving notice to end the tenancy effective on a date that must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: not earlier than 2 months after the date the tenant receives the notice,
the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement, and
if the tenancy agreement is a fixed term tenancy agreement, not earlier than the date specified as the end of the tenancy, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a purpose referred to in subsection (6) by giving notice to end the tenancy effective on a date that must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: not earlier than 4 months after the date the tenant receives the notice,
the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement, and
if the tenancy agreement is a fixed term tenancy agreement, not earlier than the date specified as the end of the tenancy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord who is an individual may end a tenancy in respect of a rental unit if the landlord or a close family member of the landlord intends in good faith to occupy the rental unit.

A landlord that is a family corporation may end a tenancy in respect of a rental unit if a person owning voting shares in the corporation, or a close family member of that person, intends in good faith to occupy the rental unit.
A landlord may end a tenancy in respect of a rental unit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord enters into an agreement in good faith to sell the rental unit,
all the conditions on which the sale depends have been satisfied, and
the purchaser asks the landlord, in writing, to give notice to end the tenancy on one of the following grounds:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the purchaser is an individual and the purchaser, or a close family member of the purchaser, intends in good faith to occupy the rental unit;
the purchaser is a family corporation and a person owning voting shares in the corporation, or a close family member of that person, intends in good faith to occupy the rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may end a tenancy in respect of a rental unit if the landlord has all the necessary permits and approvals required by law, and intends in good faith, to do any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: demolish the rental unit;
[Repealed 2021-1-13.]
convert the residential property to strata lots under the Strata Property Act;
convert the residential property into a not for profit housing cooperative under the Cooperative Association Act;
convert the rental unit for use by a caretaker, manager or superintendent of the residential property;
convert the rental unit to a non-residential use.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under this section must comply with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy] and, in the case of a notice under subsection (5), must contain the name and address of the purchaser who asked the landlord to give the notice.
A tenant may dispute

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice given under subsection (3), (4) or (5) by making an application for dispute resolution within 15 days after the date the tenant receives the notice, or
a notice given under subsection (6) by making an application for dispute resolution within 30 days after the date the tenant receives the notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a tenant who has received a notice under this section does not make an application for dispute resolution in accordance with subsection (8), the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is conclusively presumed to have accepted that the tenancy ends on the effective date of the notice, and
must vacate the rental unit by that date.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Landlord's notice: tenant ceases to qualify for rental unit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: public housing body means a prescribed person or organization;
subsidized rental unit means a rental unit that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: operated by a public housing body, or on behalf of a public housing body, and

occupied by a tenant who was required to demonstrate that the tenant, or another proposed occupant, met eligibility criteria related to income, number of occupants, health or other similar criteria before entering into the tenancy agreement in relation to the rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 50 [tenant may end tenancy early] and if provided for in the tenancy agreement, a landlord may end the tenancy of a subsidized rental unit by giving notice to end the tenancy if the tenant or other occupant, as applicable, ceases to qualify for the rental unit.
Unless the tenant agrees in writing to an earlier date, a notice under this section must end the tenancy on a date that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not earlier than 2 months after the date the notice is received,
the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement, and
if the tenancy agreement is a fixed term tenancy agreement, not earlier than the date specified as the end of the tenancy.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice under this section must comply with section 52.
A tenant may dispute a notice under this section by making an application for dispute resolution within 15 days after the date the tenant receives the notice.
If a tenant who has received a notice under this section does not make an application for dispute resolution in accordance with subsection (5), the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is conclusively presumed to have accepted that the tenancy ends on the effective date of the notice, and
must vacate the rental unit by that date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 51.4 [tenant's compensation: section 49.2 order], a landlord may make an application for dispute resolution requesting an order ending a tenancy, and an order granting the landlord possession of the rental unit, if all of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord intends in good faith to renovate or repair the rental unit and has all the necessary permits and approvals required by law to carry out the renovations or repairs;
the renovations or repairs require the rental unit to be vacant;
the renovations or repairs are necessary to prolong or sustain the use of the rental unit or the building in which the rental unit is located;
the only reasonable way to achieve the necessary vacancy is to end the tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In the case of renovations or repairs to more than one rental unit in a building, a landlord must make a single application for orders with the same effective date under this section.
The director must grant an order ending a tenancy in respect of, and an order of possession of, a rental unit if the director is satisfied that all the circumstances in subsection (1) apply.
An order granted under this section must have an effective date that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: not earlier than 4 months after the date the order is made,
the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement, and
if the tenancy agreement is a fixed term tenancy agreement, not earlier than the date specified as the end of the tenancy.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tenant may end tenancy early following notice under certain sections

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a landlord gives a tenant notice to end a periodic tenancy under section 49 [landlord's use of property] or 49.1 [landlord's notice: tenant ceases to qualify] or the tenant receives a director's order ending a periodic tenancy under section 49.2 [director's orders: renovations or repairs], the tenant may end the tenancy early by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: giving the landlord at least 10 days' written notice to end the tenancy on a date that is earlier than the effective date of the landlord's notice or director's order, and
paying the landlord, on the date the tenant's notice is given, the proportion of the rent due to the effective date of the tenant's notice, unless subsection (2) applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the tenant paid rent before giving a notice under subsection (1), on receiving the tenant's notice, the landlord must refund any rent paid for a period after the effective date of the tenant's notice.
A notice under this section does not affect the tenant's right to compensation under section 51 [tenant's compensation: section 49 notice].

A tenant who receives a notice to end a tenancy under section 49 [landlord's use of property] is entitled to receive from the landlord on or before the effective date of the landlord's notice an amount that is the equivalent of one month's rent payable under the tenancy agreement.
A tenant referred to in subsection (1) may withhold the amount authorized from the last month's rent and, for the purposes of section 50 (2), that amount is deemed to have been paid to the landlord.
If a tenant referred to in subsection (1) paid rent before giving a notice under section 50, the landlord must refund the amount paid.

Subject to subsection (3), the landlord or, if applicable, the purchaser who asked the landlord to give the notice must pay the tenant, in addition to the amount payable under subsection (1), an amount that is the equivalent of 12 times the monthly rent payable under the tenancy agreement unless the landlord or purchaser, as applicable, establishes that both of the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the stated purpose for ending the tenancy was accomplished within a reasonable period after the effective date of the notice;

the rental unit, except in respect of the purpose specified in section 49 (6) (a), has been used for that stated purpose for at least 6 months' duration, beginning within a reasonable period after the effective date of the notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may excuse the landlord or, if applicable, the purchaser who asked the landlord to give the notice from paying the tenant the amount required under subsection (2) if, in the director's opinion, extenuating circumstances prevented the landlord or the purchaser, as applicable, from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: accomplishing, within a reasonable period after the effective date of the notice, the stated purpose for ending the tenancy, and

using the rental unit, except in respect of the purpose specified in section 49 (6) (a), for that stated purpose for at least 6 months' duration, beginning within a reasonable period after the effective date of the notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2) of this section, if a fixed term tenancy agreement includes, in a circumstance prescribed under section 97 (2) (a.1), a requirement that the tenant vacate the rental unit at the end of the term, the landlord must pay the tenant an amount that is the equivalent of 12 times the monthly rent payable under the tenancy agreement unless the landlord establishes that both of the following conditions are met:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: steps have been taken, within a reasonable period after the date the tenancy ended, to satisfy the prescribed circumstance;

the rental unit is used in a way that satisfies the prescribed circumstance for at least the period of time prescribed under section 97 (2) (a.2), beginning within a reasonable period after the date the tenancy ended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may excuse the landlord from paying the tenant the amount required under subsection (1) if, in the director's opinion, extenuating circumstances prevented the landlord from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: satisfying, within a reasonable period after the date the tenancy ended, the prescribed circumstance, or

using the rental unit in a way that satisfies the prescribed circumstance for at least the period of time prescribed under section 97 (2) (a.2), beginning within a reasonable period after the date the tenancy ended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In respect of a rental unit in a residential property containing 5 or more rental units, a tenant who receives an order under section 49.2 is entitled to enter into a new tenancy agreement respecting the rental unit upon completion of the renovations or repairs for which the notice was issued if, before the tenant vacates the rental unit, the tenant gives the landlord a notice that the tenant intends to do so.
If a tenant has given a notice under subsection (1), the landlord, at least 45 days before the completion of the renovations or repairs, must give the tenant

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of the availability date of the rental unit, and
a tenancy agreement to commence effective on that availability date.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the tenant, on or before the availability date, does not enter into a tenancy agreement in respect of the rental unit that has undergone the renovations or repairs, the tenant has no further rights in respect of the rental unit.
A notice under subsection (1) or (2) must be in the approved form.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tenant's compensation: no right of first refusal

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2) of this section, if a tenant has given a notice under subsection (1) of section 51.2, the landlord must pay the tenant an amount that is the equivalent of 12 times the monthly rent payable under the previous tenancy agreement if the landlord does not comply with section 51.2 (2).

The director may excuse the landlord from paying the tenant the amount required under subsection (1) if, in the director's opinion, extenuating circumstances prevented the landlord from complying with section 51.2 (2).

A tenant who receives an order ending a tenancy under section 49.2 [director's orders: renovations or repairs] is entitled to receive from the landlord on or before the effective date of the director's order an amount that is the equivalent of one month's rent payable under the tenancy agreement.
A tenant referred to in subsection (1) may withhold the amount authorized from the last month's rent and, for the purposes of section 50 (2), that amount is deemed to have been paid to the landlord.
If a tenant referred to in subsection (1) paid rent before giving a notice under section 50, the landlord must refund the amount paid.

Subject to subsection (5), the landlord must pay the tenant, in addition to the amount payable under subsection (1), an amount that is the equivalent of 12 times the monthly rent payable under the tenancy agreement unless the landlord establishes that the renovations or repairs have been accomplished within a reasonable period after the effective date of the order.

The director may excuse the landlord from paying the tenant the amount required under subsection (4) if, in the director's opinion, extenuating circumstances prevented the landlord from accomplishing the renovations or repairs within a reasonable period after the effective date of the order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Form and content of notice to end tenancy
bcl:section.bcl:text: In order to be effective, a notice to end a tenancy must be in writing and must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be signed and dated by the landlord or tenant giving the notice,
give the address of the rental unit,
state the effective date of the notice,
except for a notice under section 45 (1) or (2) [tenant's notice], state the grounds for ending the tenancy,
for a notice under section 45.1 [tenant's notice: family violence or long-term care], be accompanied by a statement made in accordance with section 45.2 [confirmation of eligibility], and
when given by a landlord, be in the approved form.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a landlord or tenant gives notice to end a tenancy effective on a date that does not comply with this Division, the notice is deemed to be changed in accordance with subsection (2) or (3), as applicable.

If the effective date stated in the notice is earlier than the earliest date permitted under the applicable section, the effective date is deemed to be the earliest date that complies with the section.

In the case of a notice to end a tenancy, other than a notice under section 45 (3) [tenant's notice: landlord breach of material term], 46 [landlord's notice: non-payment of rent] or 50 [tenant may end tenancy early], if the effective date stated in the notice is any day other than the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement, the effective date is deemed to be the day before the day in the month, or in the other period on which the tenancy is based, that rent is payable under the tenancy agreement

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that complies with the required notice period, or
if the landlord gives a longer notice period, that complies with that longer notice period.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Order of Possession of Rental Unit

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order of possession for the tenant

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A tenant who has entered into a tenancy agreement with a landlord may request an order of possession of the rental unit by making an application for dispute resolution.

The director may grant an order of possession to a tenant under this section before or after the date on which the tenant is entitled to occupy the rental unit under the tenancy agreement, and the order is effective on the date specified by the director.
The date specified under subsection (2) may not be earlier than the date the tenant is entitled to occupy the rental unit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Order of possession for the landlord

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a tenant makes an application for dispute resolution to dispute a landlord's notice to end a tenancy, the director must grant to the landlord an order of possession of the rental unit if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the landlord's notice to end tenancy complies with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy], and
the director, during the dispute resolution proceeding, dismisses the tenant's application or upholds the landlord's notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an application referred to in subsection (1) is in relation to a landlord's notice to end a tenancy under section 46 [landlord's notice: non-payment of rent], and the circumstances referred to in subsection (1) (a) and (b) of this section apply, the director must grant an order requiring the payment of the unpaid rent.
A landlord may request an order of possession of a rental unit in any of the following circumstances by making an application for dispute resolution:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice to end the tenancy has been given by the tenant;

a notice to end the tenancy has been given by the landlord, the tenant has not disputed the notice by making an application for dispute resolution and the time for making that application has expired;
the tenancy agreement is a fixed term tenancy agreement that, in circumstances prescribed under section 97 (2) (a.1), requires the tenant to vacate the rental unit at the end of the term;
the tenancy agreement is a sublease agreement;
the landlord and tenant have agreed in writing that the tenancy is ended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may grant an order of possession before or after the date when a tenant is required to vacate a rental unit, and the order takes effect on the date specified in the order.
In the circumstances described in subsection (2) (b), the director may, without any further dispute resolution process under Part 5 [Resolving Disputes],

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: grant an order of possession, and
if the application is in relation to the non-payment of rent, grant an order requiring payment of that rent.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application for order ending tenancy early

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A landlord may make an application for dispute resolution requesting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order ending a tenancy on a date that is earlier than the tenancy would end if notice to end the tenancy were given under section 47 [landlord's notice: cause], and
an order granting the landlord possession of the rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may make an order specifying an earlier date on which a tenancy ends and the effective date of the order of possession only if satisfied, in the case of a landlord's application,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tenant or a person permitted on the residential property by the tenant has done any of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: significantly interfered with or unreasonably disturbed another occupant or the landlord of the residential property;
seriously jeopardized the health or safety or a lawful right or interest of the landlord or another occupant;
put the landlord's property at significant risk;
engaged in illegal activity that

bcl:clause.bcl:text: has caused or is likely to cause damage to the landlord's property,
