has adversely affected or is likely to adversely affect the quiet enjoyment, security, safety or physical well-being of another occupant of the residential property, or
has jeopardized or is likely to jeopardize a lawful right or interest of another occupant or the landlord;

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: caused extraordinary damage to the residential property, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it would be unreasonable, or unfair to the landlord or other occupants of the residential property, to wait for a notice to end the tenancy under section 47 [landlord's notice: cause] to take effect.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If an order is made under this section, it is unnecessary for the landlord to give the tenant a notice to end the tenancy.
A landlord may make an application for dispute resolution requesting

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order ending a tenancy because

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the rental unit is uninhabitable, or
the tenancy agreement is otherwise frustrated, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting the landlord possession of the rental unit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the director is satisfied that a rental unit is uninhabitable or the tenancy agreement is otherwise frustrated, the director may make an order

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deeming the tenancy agreement ended on the date the director considers that performance of the tenancy agreement became impossible, and
specifying the effective date of the order of possession.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: What happens if a tenant does not leave when tenancy ended

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: new tenant means a tenant who has entered into a tenancy agreement in respect of a rental unit but who is prevented from occupying the rental unit by an overholding tenant;
overholding tenant means a tenant who continues to occupy a rental unit after the tenant's tenancy is ended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The landlord must not take actual possession of a rental unit that is occupied by an overholding tenant unless the landlord has a writ of possession issued under the Supreme Court Civil Rules.
A landlord may claim compensation from an overholding tenant for any period that the overholding tenant occupies the rental unit after the tenancy is ended.

If a landlord is entitled to claim compensation from an overholding tenant under subsection (3) and a new tenant brings proceedings against the landlord to enforce the new tenant's right to possess or occupy the rental unit that is occupied by the overholding tenant, the landlord may apply to add the overholding tenant as a party to the proceedings.

bcl:section.bcl:text: [Not in force.]
In providing dispute resolution services under this Part, the director must act in a manner that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is accessible, timely and flexible, and
recognizes any relationships between parties to a dispute that will likely continue after proceedings under this Part are concluded.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, landlord includes a purchaser as defined in section 49 who, under section 49 (5) (c), asks a landlord to give notice to end a tenancy of a rental unit.

Except as restricted under this Act, a person may make an application to the director for dispute resolution in relation to a dispute with the person's landlord or tenant in respect of any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: rights, obligations and prohibitions under this Act;
rights and obligations under the terms of a tenancy agreement that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: are required or prohibited under this Act, or
relate to

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the tenant's use, occupation or maintenance of the rental unit, or
the use of common areas or services or facilities.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as provided in subsection (4) (a), the director must not determine a dispute if any of the following applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount claimed for debt or damages is more than the monetary limit for claims under the Small Claims Act, excluding any amount claimed under any of the following provisions of this Act:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 51 (1) or (2) [tenant's compensation: section 49 notice];
section 51.1 [tenant's compensation: requirement to vacate];
section 51.3 [tenant's compensation: no right of first refusal];
section 51.4 [tenant's compensation: section 49.2 order];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the claim is with respect to whether the tenant is eligible to end a fixed term tenancy under section 45.1 [tenant's notice: family violence or long-term care];
the application for dispute resolution was not made within the applicable time period specified under this Act;
the dispute is linked substantially to a matter that is before the Supreme Court.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2021-1-22.]

Except as provided in subsection (4) or (4.1), a court does not have and must not exercise any jurisdiction in respect of a matter that must be submitted to the director for dispute resolution under this Act.
The Supreme Court may, on application regarding a dispute referred to in subsection (2) (a) or (d),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the director hear and determine the dispute, or
hear and determine the dispute.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the Supreme Court hears and determines a dispute under subsection (4) (b), the Supreme Court may make any order that the director may make under this Act.
The Arbitration Act does not apply to a dispute resolution proceeding.
An application for dispute resolution must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in the applicable approved form,
include full particulars of the dispute that is to be the subject of the dispute resolution proceedings, and
be accompanied by the fee prescribed in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except for an application referred to in subsection (6), a person who makes an application for dispute resolution must give a copy of the application to the other party within 3 days of making it, or within a different period specified by the director.
The director may waive or reduce the fee if satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant cannot reasonably afford to pay the fee, or
the circumstances do not warrant the fee being collected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may refuse to accept an application for dispute resolution if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the director's opinion, the application does not disclose a dispute that may be determined under this Part,
the applicant owes outstanding fees or administrative penalty amounts under this Act to the government, or
the application does not comply with subsection (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An individual occupying a room in a residential hotel may make an application for dispute resolution, without notice to any other party, requesting an interim order that this Act applies to that living accommodation.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Latest time application for dispute resolution can be made

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If this Act does not state a time by which an application for dispute resolution must be made, it must be made within 2 years of the date that the tenancy to which the matter relates ends or is assigned.

Despite the Limitation Act, if an application for dispute resolution is not made within the 2 year period, a claim arising under this Act or the tenancy agreement in relation to the tenancy ceases to exist for all purposes except as provided in subsection (3).

If an application for dispute resolution is made by a landlord or tenant within the applicable limitation period under this Act, the other party to the dispute may make an application for dispute resolution in respect of a different dispute between the same parties after the applicable limitation period but before the dispute resolution proceeding in respect of the first application is concluded.
This section applies if an application for dispute resolution

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is properly completed,
is accepted by the director, and
is not dismissed under section 62 (4) [director's authority respecting dispute resolution proceedings].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If this section applies, the director must set the matter down for a hearing and,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the hearing is to be oral, specify the date, time and place of the hearing, and
if the hearing is to be in writing, specify when written submissions are due.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's authority respecting dispute resolution proceedings

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to section 58, the director has authority to determine

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: disputes in relation to which the director has accepted an application for dispute resolution, and
any matters related to that dispute that arise under this Act or a tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may make any finding of fact or law that is necessary or incidental to making a decision or an order under this Act.

The director may make any order necessary to give effect to the rights, obligations and prohibitions under this Act, including an order that a landlord or tenant comply with this Act, the regulations or a tenancy agreement and an order that this Act applies.
The director may dismiss all or part of an application for dispute resolution if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: there are no reasonable grounds for the application or part,
the application or part does not disclose a dispute that may be determined under this Part, or
the application or part is frivolous or an abuse of the dispute resolution process.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may assist the parties, or offer the parties an opportunity, to settle their dispute.
If the parties settle their dispute during dispute resolution proceedings, the director may record the settlement in the form of a decision or an order.
The director must make each decision or order on the merits of the case as disclosed by the evidence admitted and is not bound to follow other decisions under this Part.
Subject to the rules of procedure established under section 9 (3) [director's powers and duties], the director may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: deal with any procedural issue that arises,
make interim or temporary orders, and
amend an application for dispute resolution or permit an application for dispute resolution to be amended.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If, in the director's opinion, another tenant of a landlord who is a party to a dispute resolution proceeding will be or is likely to be materially affected by the determination of the dispute, the director may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the other tenant be given notice of the proceeding, and
provide that other tenant with an opportunity to be heard in the proceedings.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may order that a landlord be given notice of a dispute resolution proceeding and an opportunity to be heard in the dispute resolution proceeding if, in the director's opinion, the landlord

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is a landlord of a tenant who is a party to that dispute resolution proceeding,
did not receive under section 59 (3) notice of that dispute resolution proceeding, and
will be or is likely to be materially affected by the resolution of the dispute.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's orders: breach of Act, regulations or tenancy agreement

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting the general authority in section 62 (3) [director's authority respecting dispute resolution proceedings], if the director finds that a landlord or tenant has not complied with the Act, the regulations or a tenancy agreement, the director may make any of the following orders:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that a tenant must pay rent to the director, who must hold the rent in trust or pay it out, as directed by the director, for the costs of complying with this Act, the regulations or a tenancy agreement in relation to maintenance or repairs or services or facilities;
that a tenant must deduct an amount from rent to be expended on maintenance or a repair, or on a service or facility, as ordered by the director;
that any money paid by a tenant to a landlord must be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: repaid to the tenant,
deducted from rent, or
treated as a payment of an obligation of the tenant to the landlord other than rent;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that any money owing by a tenant or a landlord to the other must be paid;
that personal property seized or received by a landlord contrary to this Act or a tenancy agreement must be returned;
that past or future rent must be reduced by an amount that is equivalent to a reduction in the value of a tenancy agreement;
that a tenancy agreement may be assigned or a rental unit may be sublet if the landlord's consent has been unreasonably withheld contrary to section 34 (2) [assignment and subletting].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director, in accordance with the regulations, must recover from a trust referred to in subsection (1) (a) the costs incurred in carrying out the order referred to in that subsection.

When the purposes of an order referred to in subsection (1) (a) have been accomplished, the director must pay to the landlord, in accordance with the regulations, any amount of rent remaining in the trust, together with interest if interest is payable under the regulations.

The director may extend a time limit established by this Act only in exceptional circumstances, other than as provided by section 59 (3) [starting proceedings] or 81 (4) [decision on application for review].

Despite subsection (1), the director may extend the time limit established by section 46 (4) (a) [landlord's notice: non-payment of rent] for a tenant to pay overdue rent only in one of the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the extension is agreed to by the landlord;
the tenant has deducted the unpaid amount because the tenant believed that the deduction was allowed for emergency repairs or under an order of the director.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director must not extend the time limit to make an application for dispute resolution to dispute a notice to end a tenancy beyond the effective date of the notice.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's orders: compensation for damage or loss
bcl:section.bcl:text: Without limiting the general authority in section 62 (3) [director's authority respecting dispute resolution proceedings], if damage or loss results from a party not complying with this Act, the regulations or a tenancy agreement, the director may determine the amount of, and order that party to pay, compensation to the other party.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's orders: notice to end tenancy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a notice to end a tenancy does not comply with section 52 [form and content of notice to end tenancy], the director may amend the notice if satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person receiving the notice knew, or should have known, the information that was omitted from the notice, and
in the circumstances, it is reasonable to amend the notice.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Without limiting section 62 (3) [director's authority respecting dispute resolution proceedings], the director may, in accordance with this Act,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that a tenancy ends on a date other than the effective date shown on the notice to end the tenancy, or
set aside or amend a notice given under this Act that does not comply with the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the director is satisfied that circumstances prescribed for the purposes of section 43 (3) [amount of rent increase] apply, the director may order that a landlord is permitted to increase rent by an amount that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: greater than the amount calculated under the regulations for the purpose of section 43 (1) (a), and
not greater than the maximum rent increase authorized by the regulations prescribed for the purpose of this section.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's orders: landlord's right to enter rental unit

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director, by order, may suspend or set conditions on a landlord's right to enter a rental unit under section 29 [landlord's right to enter rental unit restricted].
If satisfied that a landlord is likely to enter a rental unit other than as authorized under section 29, the director, by order, may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: authorize the tenant to change the locks, keys or other means that allow access to the rental unit, and
prohibit the landlord from replacing those locks or obtaining keys or by other means obtaining entry into the rental unit.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's orders: delivery and service of records

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may order that a notice, order, process or other record may be served by substituted service in accordance with the order.
In addition to the authority under subsection (1), the director may make any of the following orders:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that a record must be served in a manner the director considers necessary, despite sections 88 [how to give or serve records generally] and 89 [special rules for certain records];
that a record has been sufficiently served for the purposes of this Act on a date the director specifies;
that a record not served in accordance with section 88 or 89 is sufficiently given or served for purposes of this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's orders: fees and monetary orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may order payment or repayment of a fee under section 59 (2) (c) [starting proceedings] or 79 (3) (b) [application for review of director's decision] by one party to a dispute resolution proceeding to another party or to the director.
If the director orders a party to a dispute resolution proceeding to pay any amount to the other, including an amount under subsection (1), the amount may be deducted

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of payment from a landlord to a tenant, from any rent due to the landlord, and
in the case of payment from a tenant to a landlord, from any security deposit or pet damage deposit due to the tenant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If 2 or more applications for dispute resolution are accepted in respect of related disputes with the same landlord, the director may hear the disputes at the same time.
If 2 or more applications for dispute resolution are accepted in respect of disputes between the same landlord and tenant, the director may hear the disputes together.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How the hearing may be conducted

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to the rules of procedure established under section 9 (3) [director's powers and duties], the director may conduct a hearing under this Division in the manner the director considers appropriate.
The director may hold a hearing

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in person,
in writing,
by telephone, video conference or other electronic means, or
by any combination of the methods under paragraphs (a) to (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may administer oaths for the purposes of this Act.
A party to a dispute resolution proceeding may be represented by an agent or a lawyer.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Rules of evidence do not apply
bcl:section.bcl:text: The director may admit as evidence, whether or not it would be admissible under the laws of evidence, any oral or written testimony or any record or thing that the director considers to be

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: necessary and appropriate, and
relevant to the dispute resolution proceeding.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director may require persons to attend and produce records

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: On the request of a party or on the director's own initiative, the director may issue a summons requiring a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: to attend a hearing under this Division and give evidence, or
to produce before the director records or any other thing relating to the subject matter of the dispute.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party who requests that a summons be issued under subsection (1) must provide conduct money for the witness in accordance with the rules of procedure established under section 9 (3) [director's powers and duties].

If a person named in and served with a summons under subsection (1) does not comply with the summons, the person is liable, on application to the Supreme Court, to be committed for contempt as if in breach of a judgment or an order of the Supreme Court.
A decision of the director under this Part must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in writing,
be signed and dated by the director,
include the reasons for the decision, and
be given promptly and in any event within 30 days after the proceedings conclude.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director does not lose authority in a dispute resolution proceeding, nor is the validity of a decision affected, if a decision is given after the 30 day period in subsection (1) (d).
Except as otherwise provided in this Part, a decision or an order of the director under this Part is final and binding on the parties.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Correction or clarification of decisions or orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the director may, with or without a hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: correct typographic, grammatical, arithmetic or other similar errors in the director's decision or order,
clarify the decision or order, and
deal with an obvious error or inadvertent omission in the decision or order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may take the steps described in subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the director's own initiative, or
at the request of a party, which request, for subsection (1) (b) and (c), must be made within 15 days after the decision or order is received.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A request referred to in subsection (1.1) (b) may be made without notice to another party, but the director may order that another party be given notice.
The director must not act under this section unless the director considers it just and reasonable to do so in all the circumstances.

bcl:section.bcl:text: [Renumbered as 5.1 by 2017-18-38.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Review of director's decision or order

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party to a dispute resolution proceeding may apply to the director for a review of the director's decision or order.
The director may, on the director's own initiative, review the director's decisions or orders.
A decision or an order of the director may be reviewed only on one or more of the following grounds:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a party was unable to attend the original hearing or part of the original hearing because of circumstances that could not be anticipated and were beyond the party's control;
a party has new and relevant evidence that was not available at the time of the original hearing and that materially affects the decision;

a party, because of circumstances that could not be anticipated and were beyond the party's control, submitted material evidence after the applicable time period expired but before the original hearing, and that evidence was not before the director at the original hearing;
a person who performed administrative tasks for the director made a procedural error that materially affected the result of the original hearing;
a technical irregularity or error occurred that materially affected the result of the original hearing;
a party has evidence that the director's decision or order was obtained by fraud;
in the original hearing, the director did not determine an issue that the director was required to determine;
in the original hearing, the director determined an issue that the director did not have jurisdiction to determine.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for review of a decision or order of the director

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be made in the approved form and in the manner approved by the director,
must be accompanied by the fee prescribed in the regulations,
must be accompanied by full particulars of the grounds for review and the evidence on which the applicant intends to rely, and
may be made without notice to any other party.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may waive or reduce the fee if satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant cannot reasonably afford to pay the fee, or
the circumstances do not warrant the fee being collected.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may refuse to accept an application for review of a decision or order of the director if the application does not comply with subsection (3).
A party to a dispute resolution proceeding may make an application under this section only once in respect of the proceedings.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Time limit to apply for a review

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A party must make an application for review of a decision or order of the director within whichever of the following periods applies:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 2 days after a copy of the decision or order is received by the party, if the decision or order relates to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the unreasonable withholding of consent, contrary to section 34 (2) [assignment and subletting], by a landlord to an assignment or subletting,
a notice to end a tenancy under section 46 [landlord's notice: non-payment of rent], or

an order of possession under section 54 [order of possession for the tenant], 55 [order of possession for the landlord], 56 [application for order ending tenancy early] or 56.1 [order of possession: tenancy frustrated];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 5 days after a copy of the decision or order is received by the party, if the decision or order relates to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: repairs or maintenance under section 32 [obligations to repair and maintain],
services or facilities under section 27 [terminating or restricting services or facilities], or
a notice to end a tenancy agreement other than under section 46 [landlord's notice: non-payment of rent];

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 15 days after a copy of the decision or order is received by the party, for a matter not referred to in paragraph (a) or (b).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If more than one period applies under subsection (1), the application must be made within the shortest period that applies.
At any time after an application for review of a decision or order of the director is made, the director may dismiss or refuse to consider the application for one or more of the following reasons:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the issue raised by the application can be dealt with by a correction, clarification or otherwise under section 78 [correction or clarification of decisions or orders];
the application

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: does not give full particulars of the issues submitted for review or of the evidence on which the applicant intends to rely,
does not disclose sufficient evidence of a ground for the review,
discloses no basis on which, even if the submissions in the application were accepted, the decision or order of the director should be set aside or varied, or
is frivolous or an abuse of process;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant fails to pursue the application diligently or does not follow an order made in the course of the review.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision under subsection (1) may be based solely on the written submissions of the applicant.

The director may order that a decision or order in relation to which a review has been requested be suspended, with or without conditions, until the review has been completed and a decision given to the parties.

Within 3 days of receiving a decision to proceed with a review, or within a different period specified by the director, the applicant must give the other party a copy of the decision and of any order giving effect to the decision.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Review of director's decision or order

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Unless the director dismisses or refuses to consider an application for a review under section 81, the director must review the decision or order.
The director may conduct a review

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: based solely on the record of the original dispute resolution proceeding and the written submissions of the parties, if any,
by reconvening the original hearing, or
by holding a new hearing.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Following the review, the director may confirm, vary or set aside the original decision or order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Director's orders may be filed in Supreme Court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision or an order of the director may be filed in the Supreme Court and enforced as a judgment or an order of that court after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a review of the director's decision or order has been

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: refused or dismissed, or
concluded, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time period to apply for a review has expired.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) applies whether the decision or order is interim, temporary or final.

The director has exclusive jurisdiction to inquire into, hear and determine all those matters and questions of fact, law and discretion arising or required to be determined in a dispute resolution proceeding or in a review under Division 2 of this Part and to make any order permitted to be made.
A decision or order of the director on a matter in respect of which the director has exclusive jurisdiction is final and conclusive and is not open to question or review in any court.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Certain director's orders may be filed in Provincial Court

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: This section applies to a decision or an order of the director if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the decision or order is for financial compensation or the return of personal property, and
the amount required to be paid under the decision or order, excluding interest and costs, or the value of the personal property is within the monetary limit for claims under the Small Claims Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision or an order described in subsection (1) may be filed in the Provincial Court and enforced as a judgment or an order of that court after

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a review of the director's decision or order has been

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: refused or dismissed, or
concluded, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the time period to apply for a review has expired.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The director may conduct investigations to ensure compliance with this Act and the regulations whether or not the director has accepted an application for dispute resolution in relation to the matter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may require a person to provide to the director, within a reasonable time, all records in the person's possession or control related in any way to an investigation.
A person required under subsection (1) to provide records must comply with the requirement.
Subject to the regulations, the director may order a person to pay a monetary penalty if the director is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the person has

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: contravened a provision of this Act or the regulations,
failed to comply with a decision or order of the director, or a demand issued by the director for production of records, or
given false or misleading information in a dispute resolution proceeding or an investigation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Before the director imposes an administrative penalty on a person, the director must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: give the person an opportunity to be heard, and
consider all the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: previous enforcement actions for contraventions of a similar nature by the person;
the gravity and magnitude of the contravention;
the extent of the harm to others resulting from the contravention;
whether the contravention was repeated or continuous;
whether the contravention was deliberate;
any economic benefit derived by the person from the contravention;
the person's efforts to correct the contravention.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A penalty imposed under this section must be paid within the prescribed time.
Instead of enforcing a penalty under subsection (1), the director, subject to the regulations, may enter into an agreement with the person who would otherwise be liable for the penalty.

An agreement under subsection (4) may provide, in accordance with the regulations, for the reduction or cancellation of the penalty subject to the terms and conditions the director considers necessary or desirable.

An agreement under subsection (4) must specify the time for performing the terms and conditions and, if the person fails to perform those terms and conditions by the date specified, the penalty ordered under subsection (1) is due and payable on the date of the failure.

Neither the director's decision whether to enter into an agreement under subsection (4), nor the terms and conditions of such an agreement, may be the subject of an application for dispute resolution.

If a corporation contravenes the Act or the regulations or fails to comply with a decision or order as described under subsection (1), an employee, officer, director or agent of the corporation who authorized, permitted or acquiesced in the contravention or failure is also liable under this section even though the corporation is liable for or pays a monetary penalty under this section.
A monetary penalty imposed under section 87.3 (1) may not exceed $5 000.

If a contravention or failure referred to in section 87.3 occurs over more than one day or continues for more than one day, separate monetary penalties, each not exceeding the maximum under subsection (1) of this section, may be imposed for each day the contravention or failure continues.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If the director imposes an administrative penalty on a person, the director must give to the person a notice specifying each of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the contravention, failure or false or misleading information to which the penalty relates;
the amount of the penalty;
the date by which the penalty must be paid;
the person's right to have the director reconsider the decision imposing the penalty.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A decision of the director under this Part must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in writing,
be signed and dated by the director, and
include the reasons for the decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Except as otherwise provided in this Part, a decision or an order of the director under this Part is final and binding on the person subject to the decision or order.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Correction or clarification of decisions or orders

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may, with or without a hearing,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: correct typographic, grammatical, arithmetic or other similar errors in the director's decision or order,
clarify the decision or order, and
deal with an obvious error or inadvertent omission in the decision or order.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director may take the steps described in subsection (1)

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the director's own initiative, or
at the request of the person subject to the decision or order, which request, for subsection (1) (b) and (c), must be made within 15 days after the decision or order is received.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The director must not act under this section unless the director considers it just and reasonable to do so in all the circumstances.
A person who receives a notice under section 87.5 may apply to the director for a review of the matters set out in the notice.
The director may, on the director's own initiative, review the matters set out in the notice.
Subject to subsection (4), Division 2 [Review of Decisions and Orders] of Part 5 applies to a review under this section.
For the purposes of this section, section 79 (2) is to be read as if it provided that a decision or order of the director may be reviewed only on one or more of the following grounds:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person was unable to be heard because of circumstances that could not be anticipated and were beyond the person's control;
the person has new and relevant evidence that was not available before the director imposed the administrative penalty and that materially affects the decision to impose the administrative penalty;

a person who performed administrative tasks for the director made a procedural error that materially affected the decision to impose the administrative penalty or the amount of the administrative penalty;
a technical irregularity or error occurred that materially affected the decision to impose an administrative penalty or the amount of the administrative penalty;
the director did not determine an issue that the director was required to determine.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An administrative penalty imposed under this Part is a debt due to the government.

If a person fails to pay an administrative penalty as required by a notice under section 87.5 and the time for requesting a review under section 87.8 has expired, the director may file a certificate in the Supreme Court or the Provincial Court and, on filing, the certificate has the same force and effect, and all proceedings may be taken on it, as if it were a judgment of the court with which it is filed.
A certificate under subsection (2) must be in the approved form, be signed by the director and set out

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name of the person who is liable for the penalty,
the contravention, failure or false or misleading information in relation to which the penalty is imposed, and
the amount of the penalty.

bcl:division.bcl:text: How to Give or Serve Records

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: How to give or serve records generally
bcl:section.bcl:text: All records, other than those referred to in section 89 [special rules for certain records], that are required or permitted under this Act to be given to or served on a person must be given or served in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the person;
if the person is a landlord, by leaving a copy with an agent of the landlord;
by sending a copy by ordinary mail or registered mail to the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, to the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;
if the person is a tenant, by sending a copy by ordinary mail or registered mail to a forwarding address provided by the tenant;
by leaving a copy at the person's residence with an adult who apparently resides with the person;
by leaving a copy in a mailbox or mail slot for the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, for the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;

by attaching a copy to a door or other conspicuous place at the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, at the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;
by transmitting a copy to a fax number provided as an address for service by the person to be served;
by any other means of service provided for in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application for dispute resolution or a decision of the director to proceed with a review under Division 2 of Part 5, when required to be given to one party by another, must be given in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the person;
if the person is a landlord, by leaving a copy with an agent of the landlord;
by sending a copy by registered mail to the address at which the person resides or, if the person is a landlord, to the address at which the person carries on business as a landlord;
if the person is a tenant, by sending a copy by registered mail to a forwarding address provided by the tenant;
by any other means of service provided for in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An application by a landlord under section 55 [order of possession for the landlord], 56 [application for order ending tenancy early] or 56.1 [order of possession: tenancy frustrated] must be given to the tenant in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the tenant;
by sending a copy by registered mail to the address at which the tenant resides;
by leaving a copy at the tenant's residence with an adult who apparently resides with the tenant;
by attaching a copy to a door or other conspicuous place at the address at which the tenant resides;
by any other means of service provided for in the regulations.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A notice given under section 87.5 [notice of administrative penalty] must be given in one of the following ways:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy with the person or the person's agent;
if the person is a tenant, by sending a copy by registered mail to a forwarding address provided by the tenant;
if the person is a tenant, landlord or any other person, by sending a copy by registered mail to the address at which

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person resides or carries on business, or
the person's agent carries on business;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if permitted by the regulations, by a means provided for in section 88 [how to give or serve records generally];
by another means provided for in the regulations.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: When records are considered to have been received
bcl:section.bcl:text: A record given or served in accordance with section 88 [how to give or serve records generally] or 89 [special rules for certain records], unless earlier received, is deemed to be received as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if given or served by mail, on the fifth day after it is mailed;
if given or served by fax, on the third day after it is faxed;
if given or served by attaching a copy of the record to a door or other place, on the third day after it is attached;
if given or served by leaving a copy of the record in a mailbox or mail slot, on the third day after it is left.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Except as modified or varied under this Act, the common law respecting landlords and tenants applies in British Columbia.
The Frustrated Contract Act and the doctrine of frustration of contract apply to tenancy agreements.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Obligations pass with transfer or assignment of land
bcl:section.bcl:text: The obligations of a landlord under this Act with respect to a security deposit or a pet damage deposit run with the land or reversion.

Despite any other enactment, no order of a court in a proceeding involving a foreclosure, an estate or a matrimonial dispute or another proceeding that affects possession of a rental unit is enforceable against a tenant of the rental unit unless the tenant was a party to the proceeding.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes any of the following provisions commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 13 (1), (2) or (3) [requirements for tenancy agreements];
section 15 [no application or processing fees];
section 19 (1) [limits on amount of deposits];
section 20 (a), (b), (c), (d) or (e) [landlord prohibitions respecting deposits];
section 26 (3) [seizing or interfering with access to tenant's property];
section 27 (1) [terminating or restricting services or facilities];
section 29 [landlord's right to enter a rental unit restricted];
section 30 (1) or (2) [tenant's right of access protected];
section 31 (1) or (1.1) [prohibitions on changes to locks];
section 34 (3) [assignment and subletting];
section 38 (1) [return of security deposit and pet damage deposit];
section 42 (1) or (2) [timing and notice of rent increases];
section 43 (1) [amount of rent increase];
section 57 (2) [what happens if a tenant does not leave when tenancy ended].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who coerces, threatens, intimidates or harasses a tenant or landlord

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in order to deter the tenant or landlord from making an application under this Act, or
in retaliation for seeking or obtaining a remedy under this Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.
A person who contravenes or fails to comply with a decision or an order made by the director commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.
A person who gives false or misleading information in a proceeding under this Act commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.

A tenant, or a person permitted on residential property by a tenant, who intentionally, recklessly or negligently causes damage to the residential property commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of not more than $5 000.

If a person convicted of an offence under this Act has failed to comply with or contravened this Act, the court, in addition to imposing a fine, may order the person to comply with or to cease contravening this Act.
Section 5 of the Offence Act does not apply to this Act or the regulations.
A prosecution of an offence under this Act must not be commenced more than 2 years after the facts on which the proceeding is based first come to the knowledge of the director.
A record purporting to have been issued by the director, certifying the date on which the director became aware of the facts on which the information is based,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is admissible without proof of the signature or official character of the person appearing to have signed the certificate, and
is proof of the certified facts unless there is evidence to the contrary.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations referred to in section 41 of the Interpretation Act.
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: exempting tenancy agreements, rental units or residential property from all or part of this Act;
prescribing the circumstances in which a landlord may include in a fixed term tenancy agreement a requirement that the tenant vacate a rental unit at the end of the term;
prescribing the minimum period of time for which a circumstance prescribed under paragraph (a.1) must be satisfied;
prescribing the rate of interest payable on security deposits and pet damage deposits;
respecting tenancy agreements, including prescribing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: standard terms that must be included in every tenancy agreement, and
formal requirements for tenancy agreements;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting rights and obligations of landlords and tenants that are not inconsistent with this Act, and providing that those rights and obligations must be terms of tenancy agreements;
respecting statements for the purposes of section 45.2 (1) [confirmation of eligibility], including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prescribing classes of persons whose members are authorized to make a statement,
setting limits and conditions on the authority of classes of persons to make a statement,
prescribing the manner in which the statement must or may be provided to a tenant, a landlord, or both, and
providing that a statement may be used for the purposes of that section only if the statement is made within a prescribed period of time before its intended use;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting assessments for the purposes of section 45.2 (1) (b);
respecting records to be made in relation to an assessment and the keeping of those records;
prescribing a penalty for a breach of a regulation, subject to the restriction that the penalty must not be greater than the maximum penalty referred to in section 95 [offences and penalties];
prescribing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the circumstances in which a landlord may consider that a tenant has abandoned personal property,
the manner in which a landlord may dispose of personal property abandoned by a tenant, and
how competing claims on the property are to be resolved;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the circumstances in which the purchaser of abandoned personal property acquires a marketable title free of all encumbrances,
how proceeds from disposing of the property are to be dealt with, and
imposing a duty of care on the landlord for that property;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: prescribing the following regarding inspections required under sections 23 [condition inspection: start of tenancy] and 35 [condition inspection: end of tenancy]:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the procedures to be followed in conducting the inspection;
the form, content, completion requirements and use as evidence of a condition inspection report;
the scheduling, and notification to the tenant, of the inspection;
the procedures to be followed in providing the condition inspection report to the tenant;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: defining a word or phrase used but not defined in this Act;
respecting matters related to reviews under Division 2 of Part 5;
respecting refundable and non-refundable fees that a landlord may or may not impose on a tenant and limiting the amount of a fee that may be imposed;
prescribing fees for anything done or any service provided under this Act;

respecting the return of trust funds collected under section 65 (1) (a) [director's orders: breach of Act, regulations or tenancy agreement], including prescribing the circumstances in which interest must be paid on the trust funds and how that interest is to be calculated;
prescribing calculations for rent increases under section 43 (1) (a) [amount of rent increase];

respecting rent increases that may be approved by the director under section 69 [director's orders: rent increases] on application under section 43 (3) [amount of rent increase], including, without limitation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: prescribing circumstances for the purposes of section 43 (3),
prescribing calculations for rent increases under section 69,
prescribing rules respecting the application of rent increases under section 69, and
respecting the maximum rent increase that may be approved by the director under section 69;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting means of giving or serving records, including

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: providing for different means of giving or serving records for different purposes, to the director or to different classes of persons, and
prescribing when records given or served by those means are deemed to be received;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting administrative penalties, including, without limitation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: establishing procedures for providing an opportunity to be heard for the purposes of section 87.3 (2) (a), which need not entail an oral hearing,
establishing procedures for providing an opportunity to object to a demand for production of records,

prescribing consequences for failing to appear or provide submissions, as applicable, on an opportunity prescribed under subparagraph (i), which may include, but are not limited to, proceeding in the absence of the person who fails to appear or without their submission, as applicable,
prescribing time limits for paying administrative penalties,
the matters that must be considered by the director in establishing a penalty in a particular case,
prescribing a limitation period for imposing an administrative penalty and evidentiary matters in relation to that period,
respecting agreements, including prescribing terms and conditions, that must be included in an agreement under section 87.3 (4), and
establishing consequences for failing to pay an administrative penalty which may include, but are not limited to, imposing additional penalties;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for any other purpose for which regulations are contemplated by this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In making regulations under this Act, the Lieutenant Governor in Council may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: delegate a matter to a person,
confer a discretion on a person, and
make different regulations for different rental units, residential property or tenancy agreements or for different classes of rental units, residential property or tenancy agreements.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: repealing the definition of "cannabis control date" in section 21.1 (1), and
amending section 21.1 (2) and (4) to replace references to the cannabis control date with the date that section 14 of the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act comes into force.

bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Part, former Act means the Residential Tenancy Act, R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 406.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Sections 23 [condition inspection: start of tenancy] and 24 [consequences if report requirements not met] of this Act do not apply to a landlord or tenant in respect of a tenancy that started before January 1, 2004, except as provided in subsection (2).

If, after January 1, 2004, a landlord referred to in subsection (1) allows a tenant referred to in that subsection to keep a pet on the residential property for the first time, sections 23 (2) to (6) and 24 apply to the landlord and tenant but only in respect of any pet damage deposit the landlord requires from the tenant.

bcl:section.bcl:text: If a landlord holds a security deposit in accordance with the former Act, the security deposit is deemed to be held in accordance with this Act and the provisions of this Act respecting security deposits apply.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations considered necessary or advisable to more effectively bring this Act into operation and to facilitate the transition from the operation of the former Act to the operation of this Act, including regulations prescribing the manner in which any transitional question or issue arising because of the repeal of the former Act is to be resolved.

bcl:section.bcl:text: [Not in force.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a fixed term tenancy agreement entered into before this section comes into force requires that a tenant must vacate the rental unit on a specified date, the requirement to vacate the rental unit ceases to have effect as of the date this section comes into force, except

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the tenancy agreement is a sublease agreement,
if circumstances prescribed under section 97 (2) (a.1) apply, or
if, before the day this Act receives First Reading in the Legislative Assembly,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the landlord entered into a tenancy agreement, to begin after the expiry of an existing tenancy agreement that includes a requirement to vacate the rental unit, with a new tenant for the rental unit, or
the director granted an order of possession to the landlord on the basis of a requirement to vacate the rental unit in an existing tenancy agreement.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of enforcing a requirement that remains in effect under subsection (1), sections 44 and 55 continue to apply as they read immediately before this section comes into force.

bcl:section.bcl:text: This Act comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
